`loadBalancerClass is the class of the load balancer implementation this Service belongs to.  If specified, the value of this field must be a label-style identifier, with an optional prefix, e.g. "internal-vip" or "example.com/internal-vip".  Unprefixed names are reserved for end-users.  This field can only be set when the Service type is ...`

Indeed, I can't find many usages of backticks in this file, but I didn't know if using backticks to annotate field names was a new convention.

I think here we want to mention that this field will be dropped if the alpha feature gate is not enabled. See https://github.com/kubernetes/community/blob/master/contributors/devel/sig-architecture/api_changes.md#alpha-field-in-existing-api-version for more details on this.

Also need to comment that this field may revert to false if the pod gets restarted or if kubelet loses state temporarily.
This is optional and needs to be a pointer.
changed to pointer
nit: needs a comment indicating this is alpha-level and which feature gate is depends on
Done
for pods without a startupProbe, this is true even while state is ContainerCreating, etc (i.e. before the point at which the startupProbe would have been run if it had been specified)?
Yes, if there is no `startupProbe` defined, we set immediately `Started=true` and thus we fall back to the classic behavior.
The reasoning is that without any defined way of checking for startup, we assume it's always true.

Based on https://github.com/kubernetes/kubernetes/pull/77807/files#r315329804, it looks like there are currently three cases where this is set to true:
1. when the feature is disabled (which seems wrong to me, see https://github.com/kubernetes/kubernetes/pull/77807/files#r319090460)
2. when the feature is enabled, there is no startupProbe defined, and the container is running
3. when the feature is enabled, there is a startupProbe defined, the container is running, and the startupProbe is passing

What to do when the feature is disabled needs to be resolved, and the docs need updating to clarify that the container running state is used in the absence of a startupProbe
API doc comment needs to indicate this is an alpha field, and which feature gate is required to be enabled for this to be set
fixed
According to your validation code, there's actually two keys. Please set the list keys as here: https://github.com/kubernetes/api/blob/kubernetes-1.15.0-alpha.0/core/v1/types.go#L2082-L2095
Done. Nice to know this "black magic".
Is there a policy for what to do if the pods become imbalanced via attrition?

@lavalamp this Even Pod Spreading feature only applies to scheduling time decisions. Runtime even spreading due to any number of issues like drain, auto scaling ,etc is not covered. I am making a change in descheduler to incorporate the same policy for runtime. That means, when maxSkew is not honored for a topokey, the descheduler will evict some pods and assume the scheduling will do the right thing.

Having said, i would be interested in knowing if container orchestrators like . Borg, Tupperware handle runtime spreading ? Would that be something we could incoporate into k/k ?

If a descheduler is expected to take action on this as well, the comments should document that behavior. (Although that seems a little weird to me, I'd expect this to only be relevant if we are scaling down a deployment. If e.g. 2 pods in one zone fail, I'd expect users to be quite angry if the descheduler then killed 1 pod in each of their other zones!!)

> Is there a policy for what to do if the pods become imbalanced via attrition?

Default scheduler does nothing on it - like what we are doing all the time.

However, @lavalamp you're right, the only case I do want to achieve is the scale-down case - arbitrary taking out a replica is not an ideal case - I'm going to tackle it down in Beta either in scheduler or workload controller side.
Please answer the question in the comments :)

@lavalamp probably i misunderstood your question. I think attrition can only happen by scaling down. The scaling down case can be solved in two ways

1: fix the scaling down in workload controller to account for topo constraints. I think this is less elegant and spreads the constraint knowledge in both scheduler and workload controller
2: let the descheduler handle the eviction and the scheduler will automagically fix this. although this does require dependency on an external component

>  If e.g. 2 pods in one zone fail, I'd expect users to be quite angry if the descheduler then killed 1 pod in each of their other zones!!)

What do you mean by 2 pods in one zone fail ? Do you mean 2 pods are pending ?
Let's add  godoc here too.
This file needs to be in sync with the "internal" file, which has had a number of small but important changes to comments and constants.
Nice catch
Perhaps this field should be immediately after SubPath?
Please state that this is alpha and in which version (like mount propagation above).
In terms of the ordering - I didn't want to interfere with the protobuf numbering / merging, so it is next in the list
Added comment

How is the expansion done?
What component will do the expansion?
What sources of environment variables will be used for the expansion?
I think it'd be better to describe this as "like SubPath, but with variable expansion immediately before use" or something?
Amended description
Did you consider making this a pointer for extra clarity about whether the user intended to set it?
You can also consider making SubPath a pointer. That shouldn't be a breaking change in the wire format.
I wanted to keep subPathExpr in the same style and context as subPath. I really dont want to alter subPath behaviour as it could be potentially risky and is also not in the scope of the PR.
@liggitt do all new fields need to be pointers?  I vaguely recall something about breaking older clients.

New fields must be optional and omitempty, and not result in any serialized output when unspecified. For strings, either `string` or `*string` can meet those requirements

If you need to be able to distinguish between an explicitly specified zero value and an omitted value, `*string` is required. That doesn't seem to be the case here.

In general, for optional fields that get defaults applied to them, making them pointers and only defaulting the nil value is recommended. It's somewhat confusing for an explicit `foo: ""` to get changed to `foo: "some default"` by defaulting.

In this case, since there's no defaulting, and `string` works with `omitempty`, and `subPath` already exists, I'd probably match `subPath`

IIUC the fields name are kept the same as `GlusterfsVolumeSource` for some sort of backwards compatibility and symmetry. But it would be backwards incompatible if someone expects `PersistentVolumeSource.Glusterfs` to be `GlusterfsVolumeSource` (which turns out to be `GlusterfsPersistentVolumeSource` now). 

In that case should we fix the go name (s/EndpointsName/Endpoints) now to follow the api rule https://github.com/kubernetes/kubernetes/blob/master/vendor/k8s.io/kube-openapi/pkg/generators/rules/names_match.go#L53-L78? 

Also FYI I'm planning on fixing the existing go name violations (e.g. https://github.com/kubernetes/kubernetes/pull/66097). The fix will be breaking change, but it's mechanical change and will be caught by compiler.

> But it would be backwards incompatible if someone expects PersistentVolumeSource.Glusterfs to be GlusterfsVolumeSource (which turns out to be GlusterfsPersistentVolumeSource now).

Not via the API. The serialized JSON and protobuf output is identical, no matter what struct it comes from.

> In that case should we fix the go name (s/EndpointsName/Endpoints) now to follow the api rule https://github.com/kubernetes/kubernetes/blob/master/vendor/k8s.io/kube-openapi/pkg/generators/rules/names_match.go#L53-L78?

No, we must maintain wire compatibility with all the fields of the old struct.

> Also FYI I'm planning on fixing the existing go name violations (e.g. #66097)

That can be ok as long as the serialized wire formats do not change in any way. Some of the differences are intentional, to name the go fields "Deprecated___", etc

> Thus I'm thinking we could also fix the go field name EndpointsName to be Endpoints as part of the breaking change. 

leaving the go field names the same means a client that obtains a PV object from client.Core().PersistentVolumes().Get("...") would not need to make changes
match the documentation on the internal type (this one is what actually gets published as API doc)
Done.
Sorry I'm late to the party. Is this a backwards compatible change?  Will clients that programatically interact with the API start failing because the type has changed?

It is backwards compatible in the dimensions we guarantee.

The type of the go field does not impact what gets serialized to the wire, so the type change does not affect wire compatibility (against the API or against etcd).

The type of the go struct field is changing. Depending on how a client made use of this object, it might have to adjust how it constructed a struct of this type. If all it did was retrieve objects from the API and access fields (e.g. `pv.Spec.Glusterfs.EndpointsName`) no change would be required. Go struct compatibility is not currently guaranteed release-to-release.

Ah ok, so if someone synced their go-client to the latest, then it's possible they will have to recompile, but older applications using the old clients will continue to work.  Is this something we need to call out in any release notes?
yes, worth a release note, both for the new capability, and for the client-go impact
Note that the name should be `ephemeralContainers` in Godoc when referencing the field.  I'm ok with this being a follow up if there's nothing else in this pass.
As Saad mentioned, don't forget to re-generate the API code for this type.  If you need help, let me know.

@musse When you change the API object, you must re-generate API source code.  Here are some steps:

0) Make sure to make you API change in `pkg/apis/core/v1/types.go` also.
1) From the kubernetes root dir, run `make update`
2) Follow directions when that task fails, it should walk you through what needs to be done
2) Run `make verify` to ensure all is good.  Follow directions there when things are broken.

Post here (or ping me on slack) if things dont work.
I don't have the `pkg/apis/core/v1/types.go` file. Will it be generated with `make update`?
@musse Apologies, this is the file and line# https://github.com/kubernetes/kubernetes/blob/master/pkg/apis/core/types.go#L1607
How are byte arrays encoded in JSON by our API machinery?
As base64-encoded strings
As seen in Secret objects
Ack.
This needs to indicate that `None` is controlled by a feature gate and by alpha.  It also needs to note that only 1.9 or later Kubernetes servers will allow the None value.
Needs to be fixed for 1.9 so that public API documentation is correct.
will file a PR to fix this.
Simply a rename, StorageMediumHugepages-> StorageMediumHugePages, right?
exactly :)
Doesn't it break API compatibility? Do we guarantee any in `k8s.i/api`?
I don't think it breaks API compatibility. It just change the const name. It doesn't change the actual name.

Const name *is* API. Changing its name breaks builds to anyone who imported `k8s.i/api` and used `api.StorageMediumHugepages` in his go code. Question is if we support `k8s.i/api` stability.

@kubernetes/sig-api-machinery-pr-reviews
We don't. In major updates we have a number of changes usually which breaks compilation of 3rdparty code.

diffHunk:
@@ -1,1 +990,994 @@	StorageMediumDefault   StorageMedium = ""          // use whatever the default is for the node
	StorageMediumMemory    StorageMedium = "Memory"    // use memory (tmpfs)
	StorageMediumHugePages StorageMedium = "HugePages" // use hugepages
)

nit: prefer "The GID to run the container's init process"

(entrypoint is a docker term)
this matches RunAsUser doc... I'd leave it for now
ditto re: entrypoint vs init
yay

Why is the JSON and internal name different?  Is this backwards compatible?  Or was this introduced when copied?

Make the internal name consistent with the JSON name unless there is a good reason.

This was preexisting. The json and protobuf tags cannot change, as this has to be able to deserialize existing objects. the field name can change (but should be a follow up, and address ISCSIVolumeSource as well)
Changing proto field names breaks compilation of proto clients and any cases (typically tests) using ASCII proto representations.
We need a linter check that all these names match.
Same comment here.
Doesn't this break backward compatibility?
Actually, the introduction of the non-pointer field broke compatibility, and this restored it

now it's getting odd. I didn't expect all new (and party duplicated fields) to show up here in the old external type. This is really ugly as it makes the events object very complex for the user by interleaving basically two versions.
@smarterclayton @deads2k @liggitt opinions?

The "normal" way is to add a new GroupVersion (we have that with events.k8s.io/v1beta1) with the extended information and use annotations in the old types to store additional info the types cannot express yet.

The thing is we have 'old' API which we need to fill. IIUC annotations are for adding 'new' data, not for preserving old. It's possible to do it if we create a new API and move the storage from Core to the new API group. I'm not convinced it's better in any way that current solution.
IMO we make the old api extremely ugly this way. Technically adding elements to an old API is possible of course, but I have my doubt we want that. /cc @smarterclayton @deads2k opinions here?

We typically have added fields.  It might make sense to collect those fields all together under a struct that contains them and makes it clear these are new fields that may overlap with the old fields.

I'm fine with that, though it'll make the conversion function even uglier and field selectors harder to use. I'll update this PR with new API once the discussion on how to name stuff will be concluded.

Note that some of the existing fields are reused, so that new uses of the API show some information via the old API, so it's not as simple as old vs new. I dropped a link to the proposal working doc so you can see how we got here.

I do think it would make sense to reorder the fields as in events/types.go, and to update comments here about the new preferred fields. 

I do not think we should make the new fields seem less first-class here than the old ones by nesting them or prefixing them with `new` or anything.

We should update the type comment to remove the TODO (why should users care?), indicate that this API will be deprecated once the events Event API reaches v1, and encourage developers and other users to try the new API. We can't deprecate this until then, according to our deprecation policy, but we can suggest that people writing new clients should use the new API.
Done.
Could also be `Unknown`?
Good catch. Thx.
@jessfraz Are we missing the case "when a container is not run as root" here?
We got rid of that functionality

And the proposal is outdated now? https://github.com/kubernetes/community/blob/f149433600ff1795521e7d9f2ae8ff3162394c61/contributors/design-proposals/no-new-privs.md#changes-of-securitycontext-objects
Also some tests can be deleted then: https://github.com/kubernetes/kubernetes/blob/28f6b3fcc037c3a21048160d062f6d544081bd71/pkg/securitycontext/util_test.go#L203-L212
Isn't it a breaking API change in beta type?

wire serialization remains compatible.

the old version encoded zero values to:
*  json: `timeAdded: null`
*  proto: 0x22 tag with zero length value

the new version omits zero values from the wire format

the new version successfully decodes zero values from the old version

the old version treats missing values as the zero value when decoding
